conclusion: To solve this problem, we need to analyze the forces acting on the charged ball and determine how they affect its motion.
The forces involved are Electric Force (\(\vec{F}_E\)) and Gravitational Force (\(\vec{F}_G\)).
The electric field is horizontal and points to the left.
Electric Force (\(\vec{F}_E\)) acts horizontally to the right because the charge is positive.
The ball moves in a straight line at an angle \(\theta\) to the opposite direction of the electric field.
This implies that the net force must be in the direction of this straight-line motion.
Let's break down the forces into components parallel and perpendicular to the direction of motion.
Electric Force (\(\vec{F}_E\)): Horizontal component: \( F_{E_x} = qE \), Vertical component: \( F_{E_y} = qE \sin \theta \)
Gravitational Force (\(\vec{F}_G\)): Horizontal component: \( F_{G_x} = mg \cos \theta \), Vertical component: \( F_{G_y} = -mg \sin \theta \)
Since the ball moves in a straight line, the net force must be zero in both the horizontal and vertical directions.

premise: Electric Force (\(\vec{F}_E\)): Horizontal component: \( F_{E_x} = qE \), Gravitational Force (\(\vec{F}_G\)): Horizontal component: \( F_{G_x} = mg \cos \theta \)
conclusion: For the horizontal direction: \( F_{E_x} + F_{G_x} = 0 \), \( qE + mg \cos \theta = 0 \)

premise: Electric Force (\(\vec{F}_E\)): Vertical component: \( F_{E_y} = qE \sin \theta \), Gravitational Force (\(\vec{F}_G\)): Vertical component: \( F_{G_y} = -mg \sin \theta \)
conclusion: For the vertical direction: \( F_{E_y} + F_{G_y} = 0 \), \( qE \sin \theta - mg \sin \theta = 0 \)
